name: KC_BONJOUR-no_credentials
notes: It is recommended to further validate potential Base64-encoded content in a more permissive environment.

name: KC_PRINT-no_credentials
description: No hardcoded credentials or sensitive information were found in the usr/bin/KC_PRINT file. The analysis primarily revealed functional strings and error messages related to the print service, but no passwords, API keys, or other sensitive information were identified.
notes: Check other files or network communications for potential credentials.

name: netgear-streaming-db-config
description: The file 'etc/netgear-streaming-db' contains configuration data for various streaming services (Netflix, HuluPlus, VUDU, etc.), but no hardcoded credentials or sensitive information were found. The file appears to map service names to their associated keywords to enable streaming functionality.

name: remote.sh-hardcoded_urls
description: Hardcoded Netgear ReadyShare and PeerNetwork service URLs were found in the etc/init.d/remote.sh script. These URLs are used for device registration and hook services, potentially exposing device communication endpoints. While not traditional credentials, exposed service endpoints may help attackers understand device communication patterns.
notes: Review the security and access controls of these server endpoints.

name: avahi-no_credentials
description: No files containing obvious sensitive information were found in the etc/avahi directory. This could mean: 1) The directory does not contain hardcoded credentials 2) Credentials might be stored in non-standard formats 3) In-depth analysis was not possible due to tool limitations

name: udev-no_credentials
description: No hardcoded credentials or sensitive information were found in the etc/udev directory. The only file, etc/udev/udev.conf, contains basic udev logging configurations.
